Ask questions when you need more information.</strong><br /><br />When you read this paragraph, you might wonder about the phrase <em>those in control</em>&mdash;who is making the decisions about what kids should learn?</p><table border=\"2\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><strong>Time on learning&mdash;deciding what&rsquo;s important.</strong>&nbsp; All these programs have been cut or reduced due to policies that demand more time and focus on academic areas.&nbsp; Students have six hours in a school day, and <span class=\"marker\">those in control</span> of those six hours have dictated that academics rule.&nbsp; What about those students who thirst for music?&nbsp; As John Lennon said, &ldquo;Music is everybody&rsquo;s possession.&rdquo;&nbsp; Let&rsquo;s return to sharing that valuable possession.&nbsp; Reinstatement of music programs in our city will bring countless benefits to the children in our community.</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><br />What would be an effective way to get an answer to this question?</p><p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_63c7cb3c-7c72-4457-7840-1538de0f26e4\" style=\"width: 200px; Ask critical questions about opposing points of view.</strong><br /><br />When you ask critical questions, you consider alternate viewpoints.&nbsp; Read this paragraph and think about the critical questions you might have:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"2\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><strong>The day the music died&mdash;we have lost something.&nbsp; </strong>It is not difficult to establish a connection between this incident and the loss of music programs in our schools.&nbsp; Prior to 2012, students enjoyed many opportunities to participate in music activities, including weekly music class from a certified teacher; optional, free lessons on an instrument of their choice; affordable rentals with an option to buy the instrument; and joining the chorus, a performance orchestra, the marching band, or small, select instrumental groups.&nbsp;&nbsp; Students also could receive counseling and advice offered by music professionals at all schools in our city.&nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">Few people are aware that when it was decided to cut a program, the choice was either drama or music.&nbsp; The music program took the hit for the team.&nbsp; We need to bring music back to the schools</span>.</td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Which of these is a good critical question you might ask after reading this paragraph?</p><p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_6d01c13d-8fac-e410-41ac-6ccea08cfa75\" style=\"width: 200px; Learning an instrument enhances learning in other areas.</strong>&nbsp; Children who participate in a music program cannot help but make connections to history, math, literature, science, and the other creative arts and subjects.</span>&nbsp; <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">End of highlighting.</span>&nbsp; Researchers have shown that kids who study music achieve higher grades in other subjects.&nbsp; Musicians themselves point out the connection between reading music and understanding math.&nbsp; Language and poetry have strong connections to music, using rhythm as a vehicle for communication.</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br />You read on and find that it IS what this is saying, and that research shows it to be true!<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p><strong>Predicting</strong> is another effective active reading technique.&nbsp; It means pausing to make a guess about what the writer will say next.<br /><br />The main idea of the Op-Ed tells you that the author, Henry Schwinkle, believes schools should include music as part of the educational curriculum.<br /><br />Before continuing to read, pause and guess or <strong>predict</strong> what reasons the author may have.&nbsp; Here are some predictions you might make about why he believes music should be part of the curriculum:</p><ul style=\"padding:15px;&quot;\"><li><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;\">Music teaches kids math.</span></li><li><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;\">Music teaches you to work as a team.</span></li><li><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;\">Music helps you concentrate.</span><br />&nbsp;</li></ul>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Predicting"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Now click the link to the right to <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;\"><strong>View the complete Op-Ed</strong></span>. The author did not include the prediction <em>music helps you concentrate</em> as one of the reasons in the article.<br /><br />Matching your predictions to what the author wrote lets you think about what the author left out and why.&nbsp; Whether the predictions are accurate or not, using the active reading strategy of predicting helps you understand the support the writer chose to include.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Active readers <strong>make connections</strong> as they read.&nbsp; Making connections means pausing to connect what you are reading with the ideas that came before.<br /><br />This paragraph tells you that when kids learn music, they learn lots of other important subjects too:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"2\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><strong>Learning an instrument enhances learning in other areas.</strong>&nbsp; Children who participate in a music program cannot help but make connections to history, math, literature, science, and the other creative arts and subjects.&nbsp; Researchers have shown that kids who study music achieve higher grades in other subjects.&nbsp; Musicians themselves point out the connection between reading music and understanding math.&nbsp; Language and poetry have strong connections to music, using rhythm as a vehicle for communication.</td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Making connections"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Read the next paragraph and think about what it is telling you.<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"2\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><strong>Music helps keep non-academic kids in school.&nbsp; </strong>Kids have different interests and learning styles.&nbsp; Some young people do not respond to traditional math and reading instruction, but find a true connection with music.&nbsp; These students are more likely to stay in school if they can be doing something they love while attending school.&nbsp; For some, music might lead to a career.</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><br />If you <strong>connect</strong> this to the previous paragraph, what connection can you logically make?</p><p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_86e7b547-d345-cdda-fe65-cc983ac43eef\" style=\"width: 200px; Here&#39;s an example:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>Effective measurement of a population</strong></p><p>Students who study geography are aware of the importance of demographics, especially those related to measurement of population and the implications of population growth for all inhabitants of Earth.&nbsp; South Asia is one of Earth&rsquo;s most populous geographic regions.&nbsp; Population of a region, realm, or nation provides some information, but a more important statistic is that of <em>population density,</em> or the number of people per unit area (such as a square kilometer or square mile).&nbsp; Population density, calculated arithmetically to report the number of people per unit area can be deceptive.&nbsp; Vast parts of a measured area may not be suitable to sustain life, while other areas, for a variety of reasons, encourage human habitation.&nbsp; For example, river valleys of South Asia support crowded villages, while desert and mountain areas have few inhabitants.&nbsp; A more realistic appraisal of population density is achieved by calculating <em>physiologic density</em>, or the number of inhabitants per unit of arable land (land suitable for farming).&nbsp; This calculation offers students of population a more realistic depiction of resources available per person.&nbsp;</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Understanding complex topics"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Active reading strategies can help!&nbsp;&nbsp; When you encounter complex reading material, break the reading into smaller pieces, each one a few sentences long.&nbsp; Then, concentrate on the shorter sections of the reading.&nbsp;<br /><br />Take your time.&nbsp; Expect to work slowly through challenging reading material.&nbsp; Plan to read it several times.&nbsp; Make notes of what you find or decide that each section of the reading means.<br /><br />There are a few techniques you can use as you read each section.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":1,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p><strong>1.
